results.title: Team building: How to motivate and manage people. V.3
results.brief_description: Presented by Mark Sanborn, this seminar presentation shows how you can turn your staff into a “can do” team. Part one: “Teamwork pays off” looks at achieving desired bottom line results through teamwork, 21 questions to determine the success of your team amd seven commitments of strong team relationships. Part two: “Developing a team vision” investigates three types of goals you can set for your team, fun group “games” you can play to build you team, team players vs. team slayers, and soliciting valuable input from your team memebrs.

results.title: Team building: How to motivate and manage people. V.2
results.brief_description: Presented by Mark Sanborn, this volume includes as follows; Part one: “Team communication”investigates how the information system can dramatically increase innovation, six essential elements of a powerful team meeting and keys to handle interpersonal conflict. Part two: “Motivate and celebrate” looks at five reasons why people procrastinate, use rewards that really motivate and new ways to celebrate your team’s accomplishments that increase productivity and commitment.

results.title: Amazon to ice
results.brief_description: Explore the wonderous waterways of South America from the infamous Tierra del Fuego to the raging rapids of the Upper Amazon; an area studded with relics from the ancient Inca past. A truly breathtaking journey includes the Moreno Glacier, the face of the Iguazu Falls and a visit to the inhabitants of the Islands in Lake Titicaca.

results.title: The Student prince
results.creator_credit: Richard Thorpe, Joe Pasternak and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Edmund Purdom and Ann Bltyh star in this romantic musical set to the music of Sigmund Romberg. Prince Karl is in love, but not with the princess he is supposed to wed in a state-arranged marriage. The object of his affections is a mere Heildberg barmaid. Mario Lanza provided the singing for the film.

results.title: Rich and strange = East of Shanghai
results.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock and British International Pictures
results.brief_description: After coming into a small inheritance, a suburban couple, bored with life’s routine, seek a taste of the high life and excitement by going on a world cruise. One of Hitchcock’s personal favourites, the film is a sad/comic reflection upon marriage and the lives of ordinary people thrown into chaos. Stars Henry kendal and Joan Barry.

results.title: Introducing multimedia (MAC & PC)
results.brief_description: The Australian Government is promoting informed debate about the opportunities and challenges arising from the convergence of information technology, broadcasting and telecommunications. ‘Introducing multimedia’ provides background information to assist consideration of the industrial, social, and cultural issues arising from technical convergence. The programme consists of three parts: an executive summary, general information about the emerging multimedia industry and details of the use of this technology within a variety of industries in various markets. SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: This program was designed to run on Macintosh and Windows operating systems. For Windows, at least 5MB of memory is needed to run this program. Mac uses 2.4 MB on disk. Suggested size: 1050K, minimum size: 800K, preferred size: 4696K.

results.title: Bright eyes
results.creator_credit: David Butler, Sol Wurtzel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Shirley Temple collection”.
The first big film created especially for her, ‘Bright eyes’ helped make Shirley Temple a huge box-office star and features her most famous song, ‘On the good ship Lollipop’. The little darling of a group of aviators, Shirley splits her time between her pilot Godfather, Loop and her long-suffering mother who is a housemaid for a selfish, wealthy family. When a tragic accident suddenly leaves Shirley orphaned, Loop sets out to adopt Shirley - until he learns that he is not the only one determined to keep the adorable youngster. This is a colourized version of the original black and white film.

results.title: Bob and Bobek. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Bob and Bobek are two lovable white rabbits who will delight children up to the age of eight years. Their adventures are always fun and well suited to younger children who will identify with the characters and the situations in which they become involved. We follow their misadventures as they try to earn a living. In “Around the corner” they find themselves in search of a job but disaster follows their every move. A job “At the zoo” is hard work until a lion escapes. They try their hands at being removalists in “Moving”, and are left to run “The restaurant” with chaotic results. Their final attempt is to become “The rangers in the park” where they deal with a mischievious dog.

results.title: Wittgenstein
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, Tariq Ali, Bandung Prod, British Film Institute and Channel 4 Television
results.brief_description: Ludwig Wittgenstein was born in Vienna in 1889 and he was to develop some of the most important twentieth century work on the philosophy of language and meaning. Jarman’s experimental biography is highly theatrical, interspersing biography, soliliquies, lavish fantasy and dream sequences. The film traces Wittgenstein’s life through World War I; his career as a school-teacher and eventually as an academic at Cambridge University; to his final abandonment of classical philosophy and the development of a challenging deconstruction of language which was to bring him in conflict with more positivist philosophies. Scripted by renowned English academic, Prof. Terry Eagleton, the film revolves around a series of arguments and discussions between Wittgenstein, Betrand Russell and their academic peers. This intelligent film links abstract discourse to the politics of everyday life. In the long run, Wittgenstein’s break with the hierarchy at Cambridge is not only a product of intellectual speculation but rooted in his problematic and alienated homosexuality which could not find direct expression in the higly austere and conventional environment of “high academia”. Though this film demands rigorous attention it is also a highly stylised and beautiful exercise in the possibilities of experimental cinema. With Tilda Swinton.

results.title: The Last Bolshevik
results.creator_credit: Chris Marker, Michael Kustow and Channel 4
results.brief_description: Chris Marker, the acclaimed director of “Sunless” is one of the cinema’s most compelling documentary film-makers. This engrossing film is firstly a tribute to Alexander Medvedkin, a Soviet film-maker and revolutionary, who eventually to fell victim to Stalin’s infamous purges. “The Last Bolshevik”, framed around six imaginary letters to Medvedkin by Marker, is also a mediation on the history of Soviet communism and a critical examination of revolutionary aesthetics. Marker was a central figure in the French New Wave and was involved in rehabilitating Medvedkin’s career in the late-1960s. It is then also a personal self-appraisal of the artist’s own politics and aesthetics, an appraisal which aims to investigate what drew artists to the radicalism of Soviet Bolshevism and the consequences for “radical art” now that Communism has been discredited. The film not only explores Medvedkin’s work but also the cinema of Eisenstein and Dziga-Vertov. A documentary that assumes intelligence and philosophical eruditness from its audience is rare indeed. This melancholy farewell to the dream of “creating utopia” is a wonderful film.
